Title: The Drum’s Dream
Artist description:
Gamblerz Crew and Goblin Party are two performance collectives that explore contemporary movement by crossing the boundaries of genre, each rooted in different physical languages: breaking and contemporary dance.
With over twenty years of performing on the global stage, Gamblerz Crew has established itself as a legend of Korean breaking through its energy and technical prowess. Their collaboration with Goblin Party, a contemporary dance company that sensuously expresses everyday humor and social insight, creates a new synergy.
The two teams transcend the boundaries of genre and form, continually seeking new points of connection with audiences through hybrid performances that carry social messages.
Through joint creation and experimentation, they offer flexible and daring possibilities for collaboration in both the domestic and international dance scenes.
Introduction to the work: Gamblerz Crew x Goblin Party like the saying “Wood soaked in water is tougher than iron,” raise questions about broken communities and the possibility of restoration through the entwined sweat, movement, and breath of community members. In a contemporary society pervaded by emotional undercurrents of psychological anxiety, alienation, hatred, and division, ‘The Drum’s Dream’ artistically explores a journey toward restoring community—longing for the drumbeat to echo once more. In traditional societies, the drum was not only a tool for communication and harmony but also the spiritual and cultural center of the village community. Yet it also came to symbolize something taken lightly—easily struck by many hands. The title The Drum’s Dream draws on this duality, evoking both unity and discord, respect and marginalization within a community. This work combines these symbolic meanings with shamanic beliefs to express the processes of fear, division, and solidarity taking place inside and outside the community, using a fusion of contemporary dance and breaking. The Drum’s Dream portrays a narrative of communal disarray and healing, interpreting the interplay between physical movement and collective psychology through dance.
Director: Lim Jin ho, Ji Kyung min
Cast: Lim Seong eun, Park So jin, Lee Yeon ju, Nam Jin hyun, Kim Min jung, Kim Hyun bin, Park Ji hoon, Hong Sung shik, Choi Chan bae
PAMS Venue: Daloreum Theater, National Theater of Korea

Title: Aesthetic Flow
Artist description:
Song Sohee began her musical career at a young age as a Gyeonggi minyo singer, a type of traditional Korean folk music, quickly gaining public attention and becoming a central figure in Korea’s traditional music scene. Established as a representative artist of Gyeonggi minyo, she did not remain confined to tradition but continuously explored new musical paths to find her own unique voice.
Along this journey, she released self-written, composed, and produced contemporary singles such as Journey to Utopia (2022), Infodemics (2023), and Asurajang (2023). Through her EP GANGGANGSULLAE (2024), featuring four original tracks, and her latest single Not a Dream (2025), she has further solidified her identity as a contemporary singer-songwriter.
Having built deep expertise rooted in the language of tradition, she now expands her musical world with greater freedom and sensitivity based on that foundation. The sounds and stories Song Sohee will share in the future are sure to broaden and enrich the spectrum of Korean music with more diversity and flexibility.
Introduction to the work: <Aesthetic Flow (Pungnyu in Korean)> by singer-songwriter Song Sohee, a master of Gyeonggi minyo (traditional Korean folk music), blends traditional folk vocals with modern electropop sounds. This creates a fresh and unique fusion where tradition and modernity meet. The performance features a full band, combining experimental music styles with a broader artistic vision. Song Sohee’s distinct voice brings a new, approachable way to experience Gyeonggi minyo, making traditional Korean music more accessible to today’s audience. Her deep and unique vocal tone, along with her expressive interpretation, adds a new touch to traditional music, delivering a powerful yet free-spirited performance that resonates with listeners.
Cast: Song Sohee, Kang Sinwoong, Koong Joonsik, Kim Junhyuk
PAMS Venue: Haneul Round Theater, National Theater of Korea
Review:
"Through self-composed songs combining folk music and contemporary music, along with band arrangements incorporating traditional elements, a distinctive musical world was presented to the audience."
- Munhwa News (2024)

"<Aesthetic Flow> not only demonstrated Song Sohee’s abilities as an artist, musical artisan, and authentic singer-songwriter, but also vividly brought to life the aesthetic flow she experienced during the creative process on stage."
- Sports Kyunghyang (2024)
#KoreanMusic #WorldMusic #BeyondBorders

Title: SHIMMERING
Artist description:
Lee Yanghee Lee is an artist who engages with the language of performance art, creating temporary theatre environments and presenting her works in exhibition formats. She began her career as a (new) traditional Korean dancer and actively took part in the underground club culture that thrived in Korea during the 1990s. Through her practice, Lee navigates the hybrid and unexplored realms between ‘tradition and contemporary art.’ channeling the history of her own body as a living archive. Her work delves into the essential qualities of Korean dance gestures and her own archetypal movements, addressing everything that constitutes dance itself: the body, pleasure, and form as central themes. Lee critically examines the conventions and hierarchies of ""tradition,"" that were shaped through the modernization process led by the West and Japan, and envisions a new kind of total art, a gathering through dance.
She was an artist-in-residence at New York Live Arts (2011) and Movement Research (2014–2016), and received a fellowship from the Asian Cultural Council in 2016. Her notable works include Shimmering, Aficionado, Twixt, Twig, Hedonist, Hail, Gesamtkunstwerk, Dusk, and Unlearn: Form and Cliché. Her major solo exhibitions include Axis and Feet (The Page Gallery, 2024), IN (Whistle, 2024), and Hail (d/p, 2020). Selected group exhibitions include Seeing in the Dark (Busan Biennale, 2024), Big Brother Blockchain (Nam June Paik Art Center, 2024), Theater: Post Media and Site (Busan Museum of Art, 2023), Landscape of Life: Hello Again Today (Ulsan Art Museum, 2023), Play, Pause, Repeat (Boan Inn, 2023), Flesh Stone Oil (WESS, 2022), and The Golden Age of the Gold Rush (Ilmin Museum of Art, 2020)
Introduction to the work: <Shimmering>, by choreographer Lee Yanghee, is the final work in her <Trilogy of the Pleasure of Dance>, following <Gesamtkunstwerk> (2019) and <Hail> (2020). This piece represents the pinnacle of the choreographer’s total art experience, inviting everyone to the “pleasure of dance” by integrating the traditional Korean dance style (shin-muyong), which Lee Yanghee has long mastered, with rave culture, painting, fashion, and club music. Centering on Korean traditional dance and electronic music as its two main pillars, Shimmering unfolds through themes, structures, and variations—following a format reminiscent of a classical symphony. The title Shimmering (meaning flickering and shining) refers both to the defining characteristics and advanced techniques Lee Yanghee discovered within traditional Korean dance movements, as well as to the radiant state of a dancer who, through intense and rigorous training, has fully realized the form and mastery of the dance. Shimmering celebrates the condensed history of time and the body embedded in each dancer’s unique movement, shaped through long and rigorous training. Based on the foundational style of Lee Yanghee—formed through her embodied experience of traditional Korean dance (Shin-muyong) and 1990s club dance culture—the piece requires each dancer to demonstrate advanced technique, personal interpretation, and spontaneous decision-making in real time. Born from a deep respect for all those who have encountered the world through dance, Shimmering invites both dancers and audiences into a radiant state of shared pleasure.
Cast: Kang Hanna, Kim Seunghyun, Park Sohee, Song Yoonju, Lee Yanghee, Lee Jaea, Jung Hanbyul, Jo Yoenhee, Choi Seung-yoon, Mang Esilo
PAMS Venue: Haneul Round Theater, National Theater of Korea

Title: Lee Jaram Pansori 'Snow, Snow, Snow'
Artist description:
Wansung Playground is a creative performing arts group led by the artist and founder, Lee Jaram. Lee Jaram has established a unique position in the Korean performing arts scene as the creator and sorikkun (traditional pansori singer and storyteller) of pansori works such as <Sacheon-ga>, <Eokcheok-ga>, <Stranger’s Song>, and <The Old Man and the Sea>. These productions have received unprecedented acclaim from both audiences and critics, consistently selling out performances. She has grown into an artist who is highly acclaimed not only in Korea but also internationally. Her pansori works have been consecutively invited to diverse cultural regions such as France, Romania, Poland, the United States, Brazil, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, where they have created a strong resonance with local audiences. Moreover, at the request of performing arts professionals, she has conducted multiple pansori workshops in France for students and professional actors.

<Key Artist Introduction>
* Lee Jaram (Writer/Composer/Singer):
Lee Jaram first encountered pansori at the age of 10 and was soon recognized for her talent by legendary masters—including Eun Hee-jin, Oh Jung-sook (former holders of National Intangible Cultural Heritage), Song Soon-seop (current holder of the Jeokbyeokga pansori), and Seong Woo-hyang (former holder of National Intangible Cultural Heritage)—from whom she studied all five traditional pansori repertoires. While studying at Seoul National University’s Department of Korean Traditional Music, she began to contemplate how to express the stories she wanted to tell through traditional pansori. Finally, in 2007, she presented <Sacheon-ga> to the world, taking on multiple roles as composer, lyricist, and sole performer. Her captivating performance created a significant impact on the performing arts scene.
Following this, her pansori work Ukchuck-ga, which premiered at LG Arts Center, achieved unprecedented success with sold-out performances and standing ovations, solidifying her reputation as a leading young artist in Korean culture. Her innovative pansori adaptations based on Gabriel García Márquez’s short stories and Ernest Hemingway’s novel—Stranger’s Song and The Old Man and the Sea—further showcased her creative and performing talents. Lee Jaram also received critical acclaim for her portrayal of ‘Song-hwa’ in the musical Seopyeonje, earning Best Actress awards at both The Musical Awards and the Korean Musical Awards. Currently, she is actively engaged across a wide range of genres, including changgeuk (Korean traditional opera) and interdisciplinary productions, serving as a music director, composer, lyricist, writer, and performer.

* Park Jihye (Director / Dramaturge):
Director of Yangson Project
2015 Dong-A Theater Award for Best New Director
Major works: <Death and the Maiden>, <Endgame>, <Stranger’s Song>, <Factory Girl>, <Foxfinder>, <My Eyes Went Dark>, <Betrayal>, <The Old Man and the Sea>, <The Blue Bird> and many others.
Introduction to the work:
A vast snowfield, where a song of life unfolds overnight
The new work <Lee Jaram Pansori: Snow, Snow, Snow> is a pansori reinterpretation of Tolstoy’s short story <Master and Man>. This is Lee Jaram’s first new piece in five years since <The Old Man and the Sea> (2019), and it premiered in April 2025 as a co-production with LG Arts Center Seoul. Borrowing the traditional pansori style known as batangsori—which was first showcased in <The Old Man and the Sea>—the story unfolds through the drum, witty banter, and vocal narration alone. Describing her work as, “I create new pieces,” she says, “but in the end, I am practicing tradition.” Lee Jaram adds her own unique color while preserving the essence of pansori in this new piece. Through <Snow, Snow, Snow> Lee Jaram seeks not only to popularize pansori by reimagining the universal themes of humanity expressed by a world-renowned literary master, but also to invite audiences to engage deeply with the core values of performing arts: ‘empathy’ and ‘love for humanity.’ While maintaining the traditional characteristic of the “empty stage,” stage designer Yeo Shin-dong participates as the scenographer, enriching the narrative through the use of lighting. The production is directed by Park Ji-hye of Yangson Project, who previously served as dramaturg and director for <Stranger’s Song> and <The Old Man and the Sea>.
PAMS Venue: Daloreum Theater, National Theater of Korea
Review:
“That day, Lee Jaram truly seemed to transcend the human realm. It was impossible not to gasp in awe at the cry of the stallion Zety, reborn through her gestures and voice.”
- JoongAng Daily (2025)

"It was the ultimate storytelling, utilizing even the moments that stepped outside the narrative as part of the witty banter."
- Cine21 (2025)

“Just one singer and one drummer were enough to create a pansori more vivid and immersive than any other form of content — even IMAX, 3D, or virtual reality (VR).”
- Kyunghyang Shinmun (2025)
#LeeJaram #SnowSnowSnow #Pansori

Title: in:out
Artist description:
WhatWhy Art is a Korean contemporary music ensemble that encompasses both tradition and modernity. Based on music and sounds accumulated over a long period, it realizes contemporary art through multiple perspectives. It carries out innovative artistic experiments through collaboration, preserving the unique identity of Korean music while pursuing the expansion of contemporaneity and a forward-looking vision.
WhatWhy Art places existence before questions or generates questions themselves. Their aim is not to provide answers; rather, the question itself often becomes the purpose and goal. With a focus on humanity, life, environment, and society, they create works that deconstruct materiality and its underlying narratives, independence and interconnectedness, and especially the continuity revealed through the genealogy of time.
Supported by the Arts Council Korea, the ensemble has been invited to major festivals including the Seoul Performing Arts Festival(SPAF) and the Korea Improvised Music Festival. Key works include <Music on Life and Death: Saengsaui>(2019), <One Moment>(2020), <Reflection>(2021), <Eternal Moments>(2022), <7 Ways>(2022), <Trembling>(2023–2024), and <in:out>(2024).
Introduction to the work: The main theme of the concert installation <in:out> is the concept of “deboundarization” concerning binary divisions. It approaches the relational nature of boundaries in a multi-layered way and expresses, through performance, an acknowledgment of diversity and the concepts of inside and outside themselves. <in:out> questions the boundaries of a divided world by fluidly crossing between traditional and contemporary musical styles, shaking up fixed boundaries and granting freedom to segmented divisions. To achieve this, it reimagines longstanding Korean musical traditions—such as Jongmyo Jeryeak, Munmyo Jeryeak, pansori, and gagok—within a contemporary context. Through a performance that pursues open spatiality, performers and audience members share an irreplaceable embodied time together in the same space and moment, intertwining as equal ritual participants and allowing them to deeply sense one another. <in:out> asks again about many of the distinctions made within the performance. This questioning of boundaries leads to a reconsideration of identity, often narrowly defined, and an exploration of relationships, thereby creating possibilities for new changes. By re-questioning boundaries — the unclear divisions of who or what is inside or outside — <in:out> restores the richness lost to rigid separations, allowing audiences to experience a newly expanded musical space-time.
Cast: Kang Ji-eun, Kim Woong-sik, Yoo Hong, Lee Na-rae, Lee Hwa-young
Review:
"There exist things beside us that unfold like an endless spectrum between light and darkness—things that cannot be conceptualized, things deemed unnecessary even to conceptualize, and things that have never had the chance to be conceptualized. What if countless declarations of de-boundary actually begin with recognizing boundaries, or even with a deeper contemplation of concepts? Positioned on one side of such reflection is WhatWhy Art’s <in:out>."
- Seong Hye-in (Music Critic)
#koreanmusic #contemporaryKoreantraditionalmusic #concertinstallation

Title: Your Symptoms
Artist description:
Founded in 2016 by choreographer JEONG CHEOL-IN, Melancholy Dance Company views the world we live in as a source of artistic inspiration, creating performances that reflect contemporary human experiences and resonate with a wide range of audiences. Major works include <Flight>(2016), <0g>(2018), <Übermensch>(2019), <Your Symptoms>(2020), and <Mobility> (2021). The company has received numerous honors, including commendation from the minister of Culture, Sports and Tourism in 2021; the Jury President’s Award at the 5th Seoul Dance Film Festival for the dance film Übermensch; the Best Performance Award at the 26th Dance Arts Awards hosted by Changmu Arts Center in 2020; and the Best Work Award from the Korean Dance Critics Association in 2019. In 2023, Melancholy Dance Company began expanding beyond the field of dance, starting with a performance featured in the MMCA Hyundai Motor Series: Little Ark, an exhibition by Choe U-Ram at the National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art (MMCA) in Seoul. Since then, the company has been seeking to expand its presence not only in Korea but also on international stages.

<Key artist introduction>
* JEONG CHEOL-IN (Choreographer)
Jeong Cheol-in, founder and artistic director of Melancholy Dance Company, began his creative journey with the work Free Fall in 2014. Since then, he has actively created and presented works such as <Flight>(2016), <0g>(2018), <Übermensch>(2019), <Your Symptoms>(2020), <Mobility>(2021), and <Unprotected>(2022), earning recognition from the dance community for his choreographic expertise and promising potential. With a focus on physicality, Jeong explores diverse movement styles and modes of expression to craft performances that deeply connect with audiences. Through consistent dedication and sincerity, he continues to develop his artistic vision as both a dancer and choreographer.
Introduction to the work: <Your Symptoms> directly addresses the identity crisis and social issues faced by modern individuals, expanding the boundaries of perception and sensation. Today, people live with unnamed emotions—loneliness, sorrow, anxiety, psychological wounds, and a lack of love. Yet they conceal their inner pain behind expressionless faces, rarely revealing their emotional scars to the outside world. This work intricately expresses the loneliness and emotional unease of modern individuals and, through a deep exploration of universal human sentiments, proposes a fresh mode of contemporary stage expression that encourages expanded reflection and thought. Audiences expand personal experiences into universal emotions, sharing a complex experience through physical movement and the structural experimentation of dance. Through <Your Symptoms>, audience members are invited to observe their unresolved emotions, break free from a social structure that inhibits emotional expression, and enter their own symptoms with both sincerity and playfulness.
Cast: Jeon joongkeun, Jeong cheolin, Ju youngsang, Kim yunhyun, Lee hak, Lee hyunsup, Mun gyungjae, Ryu jisoo
PAMS Venue: Daloreum Theater, National Theater of Korea
Review:
"A self-portrait of the young soul of our time expressed through functional dance, Melancholy Dance Company’s <Your Symptoms>.
Since it is a work that fully reflects the artist’s own emotions and thoughts, it has the advantage of being most authentically realized by its creator. However, beyond that, Jeong Cheol-in, who commands the stage with functional dance imbued with sensitive and emotional expression, becomes an icon of his own creation. This level of mastery, as both choreographer and performer, is a realm only a dancer of exceptional skill can achieve. (Summary)"
- Shim Jungmin, Dance Critic, In-depth Review, ARKO Daehangno Arts Theater (2023)

"Work: <Your Symptoms>. Like a cartoon where a small dark cloud hovers only above the head of a melancholic character, a water sprayer persistently chases him, sprinkling a light rain. Eventually, he becomes soaked, and the accumulated droplets bounce back in response to JEONG CHEOL-IN’s movements. The body’s expressive power visualizing emotions is outstanding. (Summary)"
- Yoon Daeseong, Editor-in-Chief, Dance Forum (2023)

"JEONG CHEOL-IN’s choreography, Your Symptoms, is an intriguing work filled with restrained composition and playful expressions. The various repetitive yet everyday expressions help form a sense of empathy with the audience, and the symbolic actions in the latter part add a sense of gravity."
- Kim Hoyoun, Dance Critic, Dance Forum (2021)
#YourSymptoms #MelancholyDanceCompany #ContemporaryDance

Title: Gyogam(Access)
Artist description:
FORCE is a performing arts company dedicated to exploring the symbiotic evolution of art and technology. Through a diverse array of original projects, including creation and distribution of performances, planning of festivals, training of professionals, and international exchange, it has actively engaged in presenting its works on the global stage.

< Key Artist Introduction >
* Youngho Lee (Director)
Youngho Lee is the founder and lead creator of FORCE, a performance arts company that uses the body as its primary language under the belief that "the body is humanity’s first and most honest universal language." A graduate of the Department of Acting at Seoul Institute of the Arts, he began his career on large-scale musical and performance stages before establishing FORCE to pursue original creative work. Thereafter, he has participated in training programs at various institutions both in Korea and abroad, consistently exploring ways to integrate physical performance with contemporary technology. Lee believes that art should go beyond expression to reflect the spirit of the times and respond to the emotions of people. His works combine technology and narrative in creative circus performances, capturing contemporary sentiments and social awareness while aiming for a deep emotional resonance with the audience.
Introduction to the work:
Fusion of Art and Technology: Crafting a New Future Together with Robots
Amid the wave of the Fourth Industrial Revolution, AI and robotic technologies have advanced to a stage where they can learn from and respond to human life, labor, and even emotions. <Gyogam (Access)>, which presents robots not merely as machines but as active performers who emotionally respond and collaboratively create narratives, was conceived to explore the possibilities of emotional interaction between humans and robots at this pivotal moment in history. <Gyogam (Access)> is Korea’s only robotic art circus performance that combines an industrial robot arm (KR300 R2700-2) with circus performance, where human vitality and mechanical precision meet on stage to create a new sensory experience. The robot transcends its mechanical nature to breathe alongside actors as a character, and the audience experiences unfamiliarity and intimacy, boundaries and connection, simultaneously in the scenes where they intersect. <Gyogam (Access)> experiments with the artistic potential of robotic technology, aiming to reduce the sense of alienation toward new technologies and expand the boundaries of art. This performance, where humans and robots respond to each other’s movements in harmony, envisions a future where technology and art coexist. The coexistence of humans and machines is no longer a choice but an essential contemporary issue we must confront to thrive in today’s world.
Cast: Sunhyuk Kim, Chanyang Kim, Youngho Lee
PAMS Venue: Haneul Round Theater, National Theater of Korea

Title: Between Glances: A Symphony of the Unsaid
Artist description: Elephants Laugh is a performance collective that orchestrates profound and dramatic encounters between strangers through its work. Anchored in the core concepts of community, sense of place, and audience participation, the group crafts performances that transcend language, delving into a rich spectrum of sensory experiences. Their practice centers on collaborative creation with audiences, resulting in evocative and immersive works. Notable productions include Bodies in the Dark (2015), Muljil1 Muljil (2016), Muljil2 (2018), 3pm to 3pm, 4pm to 4pm (2019), People from Doksan (2020), Unseen Turmoil (2022), and Chachacha (2023).
Introduction to the work: The universe is often described as a vast macrocosm, while humans are likened to corresponding microcosms. Within each person lie all the elements and forces of the cosmos, and we each carry our own unique world within us. <Elephants Laugh> has, through various performances, confronted the invisible boundaries and barriers that exist between strangers, creating moments of connection across those divides. <Between Glances: A Symphony of the Unsaid> brings together the community and performers from previous productions to collaboratively create a new work. It invites both audience members and performers, as representatives of various social issues, to share a moment of authentic encounter and mutual engagement. At the instant when people truly face one another, we discover each other’s “doors.” In that brief eye contact, a connection to another indescribable world begins, awakening senses that have long grown dull. Through themes of gaze, attention, relationship, and connection, <Between Glances: A Symphony of the Unsaid> allows participants to experience these ideas through bodily and visual language. By experimenting together with the possibilities of human connection on stage, both audience and creators artistically propose a way to bridge the growing distance between people in modern society, offering a sensory and thoughtful experience. “To face someone” can sometimes offer simple, warm comfort, while at other times it may bring discomfort and unfamiliarity. Yet in these encounters, we seek to witness moments when different worlds—too complex to be fully expressed in words—gradually come together as one harmonious chorus.
Review:
<Between Glances>, in another sense, does not vanish. By creating a new here-and-now that is neither complete fiction nor everyday life, the work makes us feel that even when apart from the place, we are still ‘us’—connected with those whose hands we once held. (ellipsis) The audience moves toward a large, very large circle. The reason they cannot return to the circle is that they have never left it.
- Yubin Kwon, <A Great, Tremendously Great Circle>

Title: Yeonhee Physics: The Quantum Ritual
Artist description: UHEE Company is a vibrant and joyful troupe of traditional Korean performers dedicated to creating new Korean-style performances and engaging with audiences. Since its founding in 2011, the company has received enthusiastic responses from audiences both domestically and internationally, showcasing the beauty of traditional Korean music and creative Yeonhee (Korean traditional performance arts). Above all, UHEE Company pursues a contemporary form of Yeonhee that breathes with the public, aiming to highlight the hipness and charm of Yeonhee in a way that appeals to younger generations. The company has gained recognition through performances such as Uheenori, which expresses traditional rhythms and Samulnori (traditional Korean percussion) with a youthful sensibility and interactive participation, and UHEESKA Ninano Pancert, which fuses traditional Korean rhythms with Jamaican ska music to reinterpret it as a unique form of world music. These works have been performed at numerous venues and festivals both at home and abroad, drawing out UHEE’s distinctive energy and excitement. Notably, in 2024, UHEE Company was selected for the New Work of the Year by the Arts Council Korea (ARKO) presenting <Yeonhee Physics: The Quantum Ritual (ver.1)>, which garnered enthusiastic acclaim from critics and audiences alike. Since 2024, UHEE Company has also been an artist-in-residence at Guri Art Hall, where they continue to create new works, organize curated performances, and develop projects aimed at expanding artistic engagement with local communities.
Introduction to the work:
The journey of the sangsoe (lead musician) begins in search of the true essence of ogeum (a rhythmic movement). The resonance of unfinished instruments awakens, and the world of Yeonhee (Korean traditional performance) unfolds through the rhythms of Jwajilgut and Ujilgut, traditional Korean percussion patterns representing the left and right sides in ritual performances.
The sangsoe maintains balance on the tightrope, guiding the flow of energy. Through the principles of symmetry and connection, they come to feel the oneness of nature and the universe. As they overcome inner tension and conflict, the performance builds toward the ecstatic climax of shinmyeong—a euphoric explosion of spirit and energy. Ogum is more than just a movement—it is the core rhythm of the universe that flows through and connects every moment of the performance. This never-ending rhythm drives the heartbeat of Yeonhee (Korean ritual performance), marking each moment as a new beginning.
<Yeonhee Physics: The Quantum Ritual> is a stage performance that sheds new light on the movement and aesthetics of traditional Korean Yeonhee (traditional Korean ritual performance). It blends the imagination of Yeonhee with fundamental questions posed by modern physics—about reality, space-time, and the principles of the universe. The work explores the secret of shinmyeong, ecstatic energy release, from a physics perspective, offering the audience a journey through which they can newly perceive the cycles of nature and the flow of energy.
Cast: Nam Chang Dong, Yang Han Bi, Seong Yugyeong, Kim Heesoo, Jeon Bo Hyun, Kim Hyangsoori, Lim Hosung, Yun Seoni, Lee Han Bi, Lim Yong Ju
PAMS Venue: Daloreum Theater, National Theater of Korea
Review:
“Yeonhee Physics marks a new era in Yeonhee, highlighting artistic methods through the principles of science.”
It stood out for embracing the ambiguous space between reason and emotion, the symbiotic relationship between ‘principle and method’ or ‘scientific concepts and theatrical expression,’ and the acceptance of the inherently ambivalent nature of ‘tradition and contemporaneity.’
“This work has become a key text and reference for Yeonhee in the 21st century.”
- Yoon Joong-gang (music critic) Monthly The Move

“The central theme of this work is the “circle.” Physics might well be understood as a means to explain the “circle,” or as a pathway toward reaching it. … Within this piece, the “circle” can also be perceived as the creators’ personal journey in search of their own circle.”
- Performance columnist, Kim Il-song

“An experimental deconstruction of traditional Yeonhee gestures, elevating artistic completeness.”
“The movements, portrayed like black-and-white footage of Talchum (Korean mask dance), are powerfully expressed through tightrope walking, creating a performance full of balanced tension and excitement.”
- Han Deok-taek (traditional performance planner), Edaily

“This work most closely aligns with the aspirations of the Creative Arts Studio in performing arts, embodying contemporaneity, diversity, excellence, and experimental spirit.
- Shin Jeong-hye (Intangible Cultural Asset Pansori Trainee), Monthly The Move
#Encounter #Engagement #Connection

Title: OffOn Yeonhee project II
Artist description:
Liquid Sound, founded in 2015, is a collective that fosters interdisciplinary exchange rooted in Korean traditional arts. Rather than simply preserving or transforming traditional arts, they seek to discover the potential for tradition to grow and thrive as an expanded artistic field.
The collective collaborates with artists from various fields—including contemporary dancers, traditional performers, computer musicians, directors, and stage designers—who interpret shared themes through diverse perspectives. By exploring uncommon subjects such as human relationships and tactile imagery, Liquid Sound stimulates artistic imagination and engages in collaborative creation aimed at discovering intersections across artistic disciplines.
They have been active both in Korea and Europe through close collaborations with the French ensemble Ensemble Passage and the German theater company Baal NOVO. Their activities include an official invited performance commemorating the 130th anniversary of Korea-France diplomatic relations, participation in a residency at the Baal NOVO Theater in Germany, the JOURNEY TO KOREAN MUSIC project hosted by the Korea Arts Management Service, and the “Korean Traditional Music Meets Baroque: Cathedral Tour in France” performance.
Introduction to the work:
Modern Experimentation with Yeonhee, a form of traditional Korean performing arts, through Deconstruction and Reconstruction
As an extension of Liquid Sound’s first Yeonhee deconstruction project, <KIN :>, this performance focuses on the deconstruction and reconstruction of traditional Yeonhee. It breaks down the distinctive movements and lively spirit of traditional Yeonhee, applying variations to movements and moods centered on playful elements from Nongak, such as Dangsan Beollim and Seoljanggu. The title combines the words “Off” (to detach) and “On” (to attach), encapsulating the concept of breaking away from old customs and attaching to new artistic expressions. It also implies the separation and reattachment of various materials. Based on the deconstruction of the body and performance props, various elements of traditional Yeonhee—such as timing, rhythm, body movements, tools, and instruments—are broken down and reassembled in diverse ways to create dynamic, transformative energy. Thus, <OffOn Yeonhee Project II> uncovers the fundamental nature and interrelations of the elements comprising Yeonhee, seeking to reflect on the very essence of Yeonhee that remains after all deconstructible elements have been dismantled.
Cast: Park Seho / Yi Myongmo / Son Eungyo / Park Suyeon / Lee Sihyun
PAMS Venue: Haneul Round Theater, National Theater of Korea
Review:
" By observing the performers’ movements from various angles, the audience was able to vividly experience the deconstruction of both the body and performance objects."
- Yeji Lee(Music Researcher), Art Criticism
#LIQUIDSOUND #Creative korean performing art #Yeonhee#TraditionalPerformance #ModernPhysics #ArtsAndScience

Title: Next Journey
Artist description:
Ak Dan Gwang Chil is a leading K-music band that preserves the roots of Korean traditional music while engaging with global audiences.
This eight-member ensemble includes two young female vocalists trained in Seodo sori and pansori (traditional Korean vocal styles), and six accomplished instrumentalists playing the gayageum (zither), ajaeng (bowed zither), saenghwang (mouth organ), daegeum (bamboo flute), and traditional percussion.
Their distinctive sound reinterprets Korean gut (shamanic ritual music) and minyo (folk songs) through a contemporary lens, offering dynamic performances where tradition and modernity meet in vibrant harmony.
Ak Dan Gwang Chil has been invited to prestigious global festivals such as WOMEX, globalFEST, and Glastonbury, widely showcasing the new possibilities of Korean music.
Founded in 2015 to commemorate the 70th anniversary of Korea’s liberation, Ak Dan Gwang Chil is now embarking on another ten-year journey as Korea approaches the 80th anniversary of its liberation.
Presenting the contemporary face of K-tradition that the world is watching, Ak Dan Gwang Chil unfolds its performance on stage.
Introduction to the work:
Innovation of tradition, a declaration of music — Ak Dan Gwang Chil’s 10th Anniversary New Work
While preserving the essence of traditional Korean music, Ak Dan Gwang Chil speaks its expression in the language of today. <Next Journey> is a musical resonance that invites audiences to reflect on their own paths. Marking its 10th anniversary, Ak Dan Gwang Chil’s new performance not only looks ahead to the next decade by presenting a clear direction but also serves as both an experiment and a declaration, translating the questions and sensibilities of the present moment into music. Known for breaking genre boundaries and infusing traditional Korean music with contemporary sensibility, Ak Dan Gwang Chil brings the full depth of its artistic journey into this work. This work creates a profound sensory dialogue with contemporary audiences through a concert that seamlessly weaves together music, video, and performance. By elevating the energy and artistry of the performance itself, it maximizes audience immersion.
Review:
“The most astonishing and impressive band was South Korea’s Ak Dan Gwang Chil.”
- Bob Boilen, NPR Music

“A dizzying show band that fuses K-pop and traditional Korean music.”
- The New York Times

Title: BARCODE
Artist description:
<Company Introduction>
TOB GROUP creates fresh and distinctive dance works by blending diverse genres and utilizing unconventional objects and storytelling techniques.
They continue to explore what it means to develop their own distinctive style and create dance works that can survive and remain relevant in the contemporary era.

<Key Artist Introduction>
*Kim Min (Choreographer/Director)
Kim Min began dancing at the age of 20, which is considered a relatively late start compared to others, but he quickly distinguished himself while studying choreography in the Creative Dance Department at the School of Dance, Korea National University of Arts. After beginning to present his own choreographic works as the CEO of TOB GROUP, his 2022 performance at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe was selected by The Guardian as one of the “Top 50 Shows to See.” Kim Min has since received international acclaim, winning 1st Prize at the Copenhagen International Choreography Competition (2023), 3rd Prize at the International Choreographic Competition Hannover (2023), the Grand Prize at the Rotterdam International Duet Choreography Competition (RIDCC), and the Best Solo Choreography Award (Solo Category) at Masdanza, Spain (2024). Having already established his reputation internationally, Kim was invited as a guest choreographer at Theater Pforzheim in Germany in 2024, and is currently preparing a new work with Scapino Ballet Rotterdam for 2027. He continues to receive invitations from around the world, engaging diverse audiences with his compelling and unique choreographic voice.
Introduction to the work: <BARCODE> casts a sharp gaze into the hidden layers of our fast-paced world where rapid technological advancement and relentless consumption mask overwork, emptiness, and the unending cycle of purchasing. With a flexible form that is not confined to the dance genre, the production incorporates English rap, text, and elements of magic to engage the audience beyond the stage. The theme of ‘modern consumerism’ expands into a universal story that resonates across cultures and borders worldwide. <BARCODE> raises on stage a question that remains inevitable to ask — throughout the past, the present, and into the future.
Cast: Lee Madrid, Jo Young-jae, Kim Yeon-a, Kim Jong-woo, Park Joo-hwan, Lee Chang-min, Park Se-jin, Jo Sun-jae, Lee Ye-rim, Son Ji-won

Title: The Wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek‘s Journal
Artist description:
<Company Introduction>
SeeAht Project is a creative group exploring social messages through personal narratives. Viewing individual stories as “seeds” that grow into wider social discourse, the group initiates its creative process through interviews and research. Its goal is to help audiences discover positive themes about their own existence and attitudes toward life.

< Key Artist Introduction >
*Yonghoon Lee (Writer)
Yonghoon Lee is a playwright and poet. He made his literary debut in 2018, winning the New Writer’s Award from Writers Opening Tomorrow. In 2022, he published his first poetry collection, <Work Log>. In 2023, his play <Mr. Nobody: The wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek's Journal> was selected through the National Theater Company of Korea’s Playwrights’ Residency: Empathy Through Creation program, earning him recognition as a playwright. Before becoming a writer, Lee worked a variety of jobs including construction labor, delivery, and cleaning. Both <Work Log> and <Mr. Nobody: The wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek's Journal> read like records of a life shaped by labor. His writing captures moments of life and work with a poetic sensibility uniquely his own. Poet Yongjoo Lee said, “This place embodies a world where life and poetry coexist as one.” Literary critic Sooyi Kim praised Yonghoon Lee’s writing style as “a cycle where prose overwhelms poetry, and poetry in turn embraces prose.” Lee Yong-hoon’s style is simple and calm, carrying the scent of labor like that of ginkgo nuts. He still works as a demolition laborer while continuing to write.


*Chiwoon Oh (Director / Actor)
Chiwoon Oh is both a director and an actor. He made his directorial debut in 1999 and won the Best Director and Best Playwriting Awards at the 2001 Busan Theater Festival. As a director, Oh has explored universal themes using experimental theatrical language. His works mainly focus on love, family, and human relationships, gaining attention with productions such as <Love, First Image – Dream>, <What Do People Live By>, and <My Mother, Jungsook, Mrs. Cha>. He pursued theatrical language that explores how audiences engage with theater, directing works that allow audiences to experience a space that can only be felt on the theater stage. As an actor, he began his professional acting career with the 2012 production <Self-Portrait>. Since then, he has performed in works such as <Mangwon-dong Brothers>, <Chekhov Reads Women>, and <15 Minutes>, primarily in the Daehangno theater district. In 2024, Oh Chi-woon received the Best Actor Award at the Seoul Theater of Tomorrow Festival for his role in <Mr. Nobody: The wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek's Journal>. His distinctive delivery and deep sincerity in portraying the character “Go Yun-ho” earned him high acclaim.
Introduction to the work: <Mr. Nobody: The wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek's Journal>, a work that tells the story of life through death, is structured as a monologue of a nameless demolition worker. The narrative expands through light, shadow, and objects, unfolding with literary language, while its calm storytelling reaches the audience through the power of the space. Through the movement of light and shadow, it evokes memory and traces, questioning what it means to live. Where old buildings have been demolished, new ones rise; and even those who have said their last goodbyes to life, tomorrow comes. Just as only a leveled foundation remains after demolition, the stage once filled with objects, light, and shadows, returns to its beginning after bidding farewell to death. <Mr. Nobody: The wanpan Edition of Sledgehammer Mr. Baek's Journal> questions passing existences and memories, embodying the ‘meaning of living every day.

Title: Light Trees
Artist description:
Theater Troupe Cheongnyeondan is a creative collective of directors and sound/visual designers. Since 2009, the troupe has adapted short stories and genre literature into performances that reflect the everyday lives of contemporary people. Their work includes original plays, collaborations with modern playwrights, and translated productions of English-language drama—all in pursuit of thoughtful, well-crafted theater. Theater Troupe Cheongnyeondan sees itself as an artistic amoeba, constantly evolving to embrace new stories, genres, and collaborators. As part of this effort, the troupe collaborates with valued international artists to introduce their work to Korean audiences, while also working to introduce Korean artists to global audiences.
Inky Lee is a Berlin-based multidisciplinary artist and writer. Her work creates spaces where the lived experiences etched into the bodies of marginalized individuals and communities can be acknowledged, mourned, remembered, and made visible. Known for a practice that is both direct and sensitive, Lee has been collaborating with Hye-mi Cho since 2022. Their first joint work, <Floating Roots>, centers the voices of 1.5- and second-generation immigrants in Germany—particularly those of queer Asians—and was developed with accessibility for the Deaf community in mind.
Introduction to the work:
"Our existence was once destroyed, and now it is being destroyed once again. Our existence was once erased, and now, once again, it fades into oblivion."

<Light Trees> metaphorically explores the mechanisms of violence. Inspired by the Japanese government’s distortion of the history of sexual slavery during World War II and its attempts to erase it, the work poetically yet directly depicts the process by which violence steals light and color, set against the backdrop of a non-human world where living beings and light coexist. While rooted in a specific historical context, the metaphorical approach resonates with various injustices across the world. The performance features two deaf artists and combines storytelling, sign language, moving light, and sound. Through music that incorporates a range of vibrations, audiences can physically sense the movement of sound. It is presented as a ‘relaxed performance’, allowing for free movement and flexible seating.
Cast: Hyemi Jo, Paulina Gullu, Inky Lee
Contact_Names: Inky Lee (Director) / Hwayeon Cho (Producer) / Haesoo Jung (Cheongnyeondan)

Title: Yutnori: The Game That Nobody Plays These Days
Introduction to the work: <Yutnori: The Game That Nobody Plays These Days> is a reimagining of the late playwrigh Yoon Jo-byeong’s 1981 play <Yutnori>. In an age of accelerating technological advancement, materialism, and individualism, the work poses a fundamental question: “Where are we heading?” Through this, it invites pause, reflection, and awareness of life’s deeper values. Using the traditional Korean board game yutnori as a metaphor, the performance explores life’s unpredictability and cyclical nature, offering audiences a space for contemplation. The five outcomes of the game—Do, Gae, Geol, Yut, and Mo—symbolize the various phases of life, encouraging expanded perception. Within the game, the characters’ lives and deaths, past and present, intersect and overlap. With minimal theatrical tools—chalk-drawn boards, hands mimicking yut sticks, the sound of funeral chants and oral percussion—the piece lays bare the fragmentation and isolation of contemporary society. Our days, uncertain and unknowable, are likened to yut sticks: only by throwing them can we know where we’re going. This performance bridges tradition and modernity in Korean theater, offering a universal reflection on life and a rich artistic experience through new interpretations and expressions.
Cast: Kang ill, Sung-eun Kwak, Cheol-hoon Han, Kang-min Lee, Seul-gi Yoon, Jeong Hong Ku
Review:
"The Yut board holds all the emotions of life — joy, anger, sorrow, and pleasure.
Lee Chul-hui directs <Yutnori: The Game That Nobody Plays These Days> As yutnori board grows heavier, life and its meaning become clearer.”
- Kim Geon-pyo, Maeil Shinmun (2025)

"A round of play that resists speed and efficiency... Theater Company Cornerstone’s ‘Yutnori: The Game That Nobody Plays These Days"
- Theater critic Baek Laura, Smart Daily News (2025)

“Who would have thought a game of yutnori could be this fun?”
- OhmyNews (2024)

“A sorrowful yet soulful round of yutnori reflects our very own lives.”
- Kim Ki-ran, Theater Critique (2025)

"<Yutnori>, Directed by Lee Chul-hui and Written by Yoon Jo-byeong, Selected as a Recommended Work in the First Half of the 12th Edaily Culture Awards
This reimagined production of Yutnori weaves the truths of life into a single game, highlighting the beauty of slowness."
— Edaily (2025)

Title: Chair,Table,Chair
Artist description: Team Funniest is a performing arts company established on the dictionary meaning of “funniest” — the most joyful, the most entertaining — with the philosophy of delivering joy through art and bringing laughter to audiences. The company focuses its creative work on circus comedy in a nonverbal performance format that transcends the barriers of language and age, aiming to create performing arts that anyone, regardless of gender or generation, can easily access and empathize with. Since its founding, Funniest has actively performed on a wide variety of stages both in Korea and abroad, sharing artistic delight and inspiration with countless audiences. Looking ahead, Funniest aspires to continue communicating with more people and spreading the value of art through creative performance content based on the universality and joy of art.
Introduction to the work: <Chair, Table, Chair> is a performance that delicately and playfully portrays moments of meeting and farewell, centering on one of the most familiar objects in our daily lives—the chair. Stories that arise from the time spent sitting on a chair are vividly expressed through circus, mime, acrobatics, and live jazz, stimulating the audience’s emotions and imagination. Each chapter unfolds like a scene from everyday life, where the performers’ movements and music come together to create a special stage that shares the value of ordinary moments and the depth of human feeling.
Director: Kim Hee Myeong , Choi Dae Sung
Cast: Kim Hee Myeong , Choi Dae Sung, Sim Jae Sung, Kim Han Sang, Lee Won Ho
PAMS Venue: Daloreum Theater, National Theater of Korea

Title: Not of This World
Artist description: Nakedblues is a creative collective that explores the themes of isolation, anger, growth, and healing through a sensory and evocative lens, posing questions and offering resonance to both teenage and young adult audiences. Beginning with the play Not Of This World, we are now developing the second work in our “World Series,” Beyond This World. Through this trilogy project, we aim to go beyond the form of theater itself, leaving questions and emotions in the hearts of our audience.
Introduction to the work: <Not of This World> begins with the anger and loneliness of adolescents left behind by society. It confronts the isolation and wounds of adolescence head-on, while capturing their underlying desire to survive and live. Individual anger and isolation are no longer a problem confined to a single generation—they also signal the disconnection and distrust present in our world today. As both a youth-centered play and a contemporary work, <Not of This World> brings to the stage the voices of young people that society has overlooked, focusing on the sense of life and posing questions that we, as members of the contemporary world, must face together.
Cast: Ye Eun Kim, Jae Young Bae
Contact_Names: Ye Eun Kim / Jeong Yeon Lee
Review:
"By delving deeply into the anxiety, sorrow, and melancholy of adolescence, the work created a highly accomplished dramatic story that moved its audience profoundly.”
— International Association of Theatre for Children and Young People Jury"

Title: Swipe!
Artist description: Ummeeonn is a contemporary theater company based in Seoul. We understand theater as a network of multiple, temporarily existing relationships. We explore what forms of relationships can inscribe political and aesthetic moments in the city.
Introduction to the work: <Swipe!> is a reimagining of Hamlet through the prisms of AI, the posthuman, science fiction (SF), and the nonhuman. It poses the question: Can what is created from the encounter between humans and objects be called a heart? In asking about the heart of a new era, it reinterprets traditional theater in diverse contexts. Through collaboration with Diana Band, which creates soundscapes through the resonance of various materials, and by utilizing live cameras that layer blind spots before the audience’s eyes in a cubist fashion, the work reconstructs the theater as an unfamiliar and curious space. Bodies tremble together in that world of subscendence, while sharing political and aesthetic questions with the audience.
Cast: Kim JoongYeop, Lee Joohyub, Jeon hyein, Hur Yunkyung
